Award.AwardTitle: Development of a Climatology of Precipitation System Organization in North Carolina to Improve Climate Precipitation Forecasts
Award.AbstractNarration:
Since no major rivers flow into the State of North Carolina, precipitation falling within the state is the primary natural source of water to replenish that region's rivers, soils, and groundwater reservoirs. As climate and population pressures change, water management and sustainability policies in North Carolina will be increasingly dependent on an improved understanding of precipitation variability in that region.

Intellectual merit:
The premise of this study is that a novel climatology of precipitation system mode of delivery in North Carolina, developed with newly available high resolution precipitation and three-dimensional radar reflectivity datasets, will lead to improved regional climate and hydrological forecasts. Mode of delivery refers to the spatial, temporal and water phase characteristics of a precipitation system. Examples of mode of delivery that occur in North Carolina within various synoptic regimes include short duration and spatially heterogeneous convective cells, large mesoscale convective systems, widespread long-lasting frontal precipitation, tropical cyclones, and winter precipitation. Each mode of delivery may produce similar time-averaged precipitation totals, but have very different climate and hydrological impacts. A mode of delivery climatology will provide a unique tool for process-based downscaling of climate simulations to the watershed scale.

The project will consist of three main parts, as follows. 1) The first part aims to develop and implement a methodology to identify the distinct mode of delivery of rainfall, which will be applied to five years (2006-2010) of the National Mosaic and Multi-sensor Quantitative Precipitation Estimation (NMQ) radar reflectivity and precipitation datasets. We will leverage a partnership between the University of North Carolina Renaissance Computing Institute, and the National Climate Data Center to analyze regional NMQ data sets constructed for this project using data-mining techniques for computational efficiency. 2) The second part of the project will examine the relationship between mode of delivery of rainfall and the dominant regimes of the synoptic-scale flow and intraseasonal-to-interannual climate variability. 3) The third part of this study will test the hypothesis that for seasonal time scales and regional spatial scales, the mode of delivery of rainfall provides a basis for the process-based downscaling (tied to different synoptic regimes) of precipitation in reanalysis products and climate model simulations.



Broader impacts:
The project will have significant implications for climate prediction for a region (North Carolina) where those connections have not been fully explored. The climatology will result in improvements to regional climate model forecasting and with future applications to improve hydrological simulations on the watershed scale. The project also include significant benefits to NOAA and NASA hydrological research and operational programs (NOAA Hydrometeorological Testbed-Southeast and NASA Global Precipitation Mission). The project will provide a platform for undergraduate and graduate student research and training. Project results and outreach will benefit the agricultural communities in eastern North Carolina, which have been historically underserved with respect to educational and economic opportunities, while at the same time have been vulnerable to severe weather and flood-related hazards. The success of this project will improve a process-based downscaling of climate model precipitation estimates to the regional and watershed scale.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We rely on climate models to give us guidance for the expected changes to precipitation patterns as the Earth continues to warm over the coming decades. Predicting trends in regional precipitation is difficult for climate models since they do not represent the physics of individual precipitation systems very well. For example, the detailed processes that determine whether precipitation is predominantly organized as small thunderstorms the size of a city, or large groups of thunderstorms the size of a state, are not well represented or accurately predicted in climate models.

To help with that problem, our project attempted to link the most predictable aspects of climate, such as the change in seasons, with the statistical properties of precipitation organization. We were successful at demonstrating that the scale of precipitation organization, as characterized by precipitation feature size measured by weather radar, has a connection to seasonal and day-night changes in the atmosphere due to the daily and seasonal changes in solar energy reaching the Earth. In this way, we expect that predictable seasonal changes in the atmosphere can be related to associated trends in precipitation organization provided by our study. This connection provides an important constraint on the predictions of regional precipitation change in a climate model, as well as a way to validate the model predictions.

Our group at East Carolina University partnered with the National Centers for Environmental Information (NCEI) to harness a detailed series of 15-minute precipitation maps for the southeastern United States for a four-year period. We created a methodology to analyze the precipitation from isolated precipitation features (like small thunderstorms) and from mesoscale precipitation features (such as widespread rainy regions). We found that the isolated precipitation uniquely responded to daily and seasonal changes in atmospheric conditions. Further, we quantified how much precipitation in each season is linked to a weather pattern that produces low pressure systems (with cold and warm fronts), which is a phenomenon that can be simulated in a climate model. 

In order to get a clearer picture of the connection between seasonal changes in the atmosphere and precipitation organization, we then examined individual precipitation events that were associated with strong solar heating and the 'sea breeze' phenomenon during the summertime in the southeastern coastal region of the United States. We found that variations in a large scale feature of the atmospheric wind pattern, called the North Atlantic subtropical high, influence precipitation organization associated with the sea breeze. We learned that the day/night changes in the thermodynamic energy content in the air over land versus over ocean drive the behavior of isolated precipitation features. Furthermore, to better understand the response of the behavior of surface water to precipitation organization, we examined the hydrological impacts of water flow in river basins to the observed changes in the precipitation organization from the coastal region to the inland mountains in North Carolina.

The project has helped to train the next generation of climate researchers by involving our graduate and undergraduate students in the design and implementation of this research. Our graduate students have regularly presented their research at important national conferences in atmospheric science and forecasting, allowing them to interact with experts in their field and to develop professional contacts. One of our students has led the effort to establish a regional atmospheric modeling capability at East Carolina University, which will have a tremendous impact on the educational opportunity of our atmospheric science students. In addition, project faculty and staff regularly participate in public events and fora to engage the community in climate science. These events have ranged from K-12 school presentations, to the national Foreign Policy Association’s Great Decisions lecture series at ECU on climate science, using our project as a bridge to engage the public on science. For the past two years, Dr. Rickenbach has engaged Congressional leaders in Washington D.C. on how his research fit in to the effort on developing climate science in order to aid in federal policy deliberation. 

In summary, our work has established important connections between precipitation organization and the large-scale seasonal changes in the atmosphere. These connections should help to improve our predictions of future changes in rainfall patterns. This project has further provided important career training and advancement for our students, built educational opportunities at our university, and have allowed us to engage the public and policymakers on climate science issues.
